src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=x-sXRbkAUPs:691IhNmCOK0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/x-sXRbkAUPs\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 20:20:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8df4cdc21cfb0019468e17?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"4f115a6f55fa28dbb7f156b7b27237f2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn41@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-13-179_adc4f717bd845db2.webp","destWidth":3952,"destHeight":2964,"sourceBytes":247380,"destBytes":247380,"author":"hbrueck@businessinsider.com (Hilary Brueck)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f2c39b0aee6a8404d684948?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn43@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-15-989_13d5be32603015cf.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f8df610c21cfb0019468e27?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn72@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-22-798_bd1a7dd5c21af178.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f8ddb98c21cfb0019468d71?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn84@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-17-983_38518e2a5d23aec6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7742800ab50d00184add1c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn12@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-15-790_a9bc79744619ef95.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=x-sXRbkAUPs:691IhNmCOK0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn64@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-25-117_b073f1c1df90cc52.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=x-sXRbkAUPs:691IhNmCOK0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn41@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-12-826_bd848632799394c5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=x-sXRbkAUPs:691IhNmCOK0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn99@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-16-401_1cefd41db119af67.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/x-sXRbkAUPs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-45-412_e6dc5fae3a728236.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473310},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"The rise and fall of Juicy Couture","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/rise-and-fall-of-juicy-couture-tracksuits-2019-11","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/gWb8jRwe-jZbcmOYf.html\"\nwidth=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"auto\" title=\"The rise and fall of Juicy Couture\"\nstyle=\"position:absolute;\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/juicy-couture\">Juicy Couture's</a> founders started the company with just $200.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>Celebrity tabloid culture helped establish Juicy's tracksuits and accessories as an iconic part of early 2000s fashion.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>By 2008, Juicy Couture was making $605 million in sales.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>But following the Great Recession, the brand struggled to connect with consumers and was sold for a fraction of what it once generated in sales.</strong></li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.</a></strong></li>\n</ul><p><em>Following is a transcription of the video.</em></p><p><strong>Irene Kim:</strong> Juicy Couture was an iconic part of early 2000s fashion. Its velour tracksuits and matching oversized bags were everything and everywhere. But Juicy went from making $605 million in sales at its peak in 2008 to being sold for less than a third of that five years later. So, what happened?</p><p>Juicy's story begins with these two ladies, Gela Nash-Taylor and Pamela Skaist-Levy. They met while working at a Los Angeles boutique in 1988. When Nash-Taylor became pregnant, she couldn't find any fashionable maternity clothing. As a solution, she started making maternity pants out of her husband's jeans, which inspired her and Skaist-Levy to start a maternity clothing line, Travis Jeans for the Baby in You. The pair's stylish maternity jeans took off, despite their $89 price tag.</p><p>By the early 1990s, it expanded into a full maternity line. But around 1994, after feeling like they lost touch with the maternity market, the pair decided to pivot to something new: developing the perfect luxury V-neck shirt. Nash-Taylor and Skaist-Levy focused on four things: fit, fabric, comfort, and color. They both tried on their samples to make sure the V-neck covered the right part of the arm, didn't plunge too deep, and, overall, made your body look as good as possible, things male designers fitting T-shirts on size 0 models maybe weren't taking into consideration. After perfecting their design, they released it in 26 colors under their new label, Juicy Couture.</p><p>When Juicy first started in 1995, the economy was beginning to recover from the 1990 to 1991 recession, and consumers were hungry for expensive, or at least expensive-sounding, products. So Nash-Taylor and Skaist-Levy wanted the brand name to convey luxury. They also loved the irony of naming their casual T-shirt line \"couture.\" Juicy Couture quickly grew in popularity and expanded to include knit tops, accessories, and a successful Juicy Jeans line. But it wasn't the full-fledged lifestyle brand its founders wanted it to be...yet.</p><p>Nash-Taylor and Skaist-Levy looked to the brands they grew up with during the '60s and '70s for ideas. Both thought terry cloth was \"the most amazing 1970s fabric\" and came up with a line of tops and bottoms made from it.</p><p>The silhouette of what would become Juicy's signature tracksuit was created with the same purpose as the original Juicy V-neck: to be as flattering as possible. The zip-up hoodie was designed with front pockets to hide any stomach pooch and cut with an hourglass shape to nip in your waist. Nash-Taylor and Skaist-Levy also added custom hardware: a J-pull zipper that branded every tracksuit as uniquely Juicy Couture.</p><p>The tracksuit bottoms were originally made with an underwear elastic, but when that proved to be too loose, Juicy's founders switched to a quick cord they'd used for their maternity line. It worked perfectly. Juicy Couture released its now iconic tracksuits in 2001, and they became a phenomenon.</p><p>Not to mention, at $155, Juicy Couture's tracksuits weren't cheap, but they were accessible.</p><p><strong>Julia DiNardo:</strong> The price point was a little bit high for essentially a glorified sweatshirt, but with a little bit of midriff showing, the cool bootleg, and seeing celebrities in some oversized sunglasses wearing it out and about, it kind of met that balance of just-within-reach pricing and somewhat of a luxury item pooled into one.</p><p><strong>Kim:</strong> And it was seeing celebrities wear Juicy Couture that really drove the brand's success. Around the time Juicy Couture launched, tabloid celebrities like Paris Hilton and Lindsay Lohan were becoming a national obsession. Tabloids like Us Weekly and People were documenting everything America's favorite stars were doing, and Juicy was able to take advantage of it. Because its founders didn't have the funds for traditional marketing, they got creative, gifting tracksuits to celebrities.</p><p>While this is pretty common today, Skaist-Levy and Nash-Taylor were one of the first to do it. They didn't find success overnight, but eventually Juicy's tracksuits were being seen on all the right celebrities.</p><p><strong>DiNardo:</strong> The attraction to celebrity culture in the early 2000s is really what contributed Juicy to become such a popular brand. It really was the height of: \"Celebrities! They're just like us.\" Seeing Britney Spears go get a cup of coffee at Starbucks in her Juicy Couture tracksuits, seeing Paris Hilton shopping all over town in her Juicy Couture tracksuit.</p><p><strong>Kim:</strong> Juicy's founders even kept a photo wall of every celebrity who wore their tracksuit. Soon, Juicy Couture was exclusively sold at upscale department stores like Bergdorf Goodman and Saks Fifth Avenue. In 2003, Juicy Couture was purchased by Liz Claiborne, now known as Kate Spade &#38; Company, for $226 million to be paid over a five-year period.</p><p>Juicy was colorful, fun, and covered in logos during a time when people couldn't get enough of showing off the brands they were buying and wearing.</p><p><strong>DiNardo:</strong> It wouldn't be a Juicy product without the Juicy label or insignia or logo of some kind.</p><p><strong>Skaist-Levy:</strong> It makes people happy.</p><p><strong>Nash-Taylor:</strong> Juicy, it is, it's a happy brand. People love it.</p><p><strong>Kim:</strong> Net sales nearly doubled from 2006 to 2007. By 2008, Juicy Couture had 100 stores generating a total of $605 million in sales. The brand also expanded to include jewelry and a successful fragrance line with Elizabeth Arden. But then the recession hit.</p><p>While most brands struggled following the recession, Juicy Couture's flashy branding particularly stopped resonating with customers.</p><p><strong>DiNardo:</strong> So, during the 2008 recession, fashion was at a point where the \"it\" bag was really not an \"it\" thing anymore. It felt a little bit too gregarious, over the top, and proud in the wrong way, so things started to recede; not that people weren't shopping, but they weren't buying things that were so blatant as to what they were and how much they cost.</p><p><strong>Kim:</strong> The recession inspired a movement towards minimalism, which was pretty much the opposite of what Juicy Couture embodied.</p><p><strong>DiNardo:</strong> Juicy as a label was all about that flashiness and that fun. And so, there was a somberness to fashion, a seriousness, after 2008, and it really wasn't on-brand for Juicy.</p><p><strong>Kim:</strong> Sales fell 11% year-over-year in 2009. In 2010, founders Skaist-Levy and Nash-Taylor left the company, citing a loss of ability to help their brand evolve. Sale numbers continued to drop as Juicy failed to keep up with the growing contemporary fashion market. While labels like Alexander Wang and Theory quickly pivoted to add more pieces to their collections, Juicy didn't.</p><p>In 2013, Juicy Couture was officially sold to Authentic Brands Group for $195 million. The company has an eclectic portfolio, including the licensing rights for the estates of Elvis Presley and Marilyn Monroe. The group announced plans to close all of Juicy Couture's US stores but said it would reopen five to 10 as it rebuilds the brand. ABG later made a deal with discount retailer Kohl's to sell Juicy-branded products, effectively abandoning the brand's veneer of luxury for many loyal fans.</p><p>Despite its fall from department store to discount bin, Juicy Couture has been angling for a comeback for years. A 2016 collaboration with cult fashion brand Vetements re-sparked interested and lent Juicy some street cred. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kylie-jenner-juicy-couture-2017-1\">Kylie Jenner even posted a picture wearing a pricey tracksuit from the collection.</a></p><p>In 2017, Juicy Couture appointed Hollywood stylist Jamie Mizrahi as its new creative director. The brand debuted its new collection with a New York Fashion Week party with OG Juicy Couture lover and living brand embodiment Paris Hilton. Pieces from the collection were available on Juicy's website, as well as Nordstrom and Bloomingdale's, with prices ranging from $30 to $400. This marked an upscale pivot for the brand after being sold at Kohl's since 2014.</p><p>In 2018, Juicy Couture released its first-ever runway collection to show pieces from its main contemporary line, Juicy Couture Black Label. It also released two new cosmetic collections, which have been met with varying degrees of excitement. As for whether we'll be seeing Juicy's tracksuit everywhere again:</p><p><strong>DiNardo:</strong> I think they could capitalize on those customers that were in their teens or late teens when the brand was popular. Now those women are moms, and they want something comfortable but pulled together. It's quite possible that the tracksuit could be that item.</p><p><strong>Kim:</strong> Plus, Juicy Couture could fit right into the athleisure market that's continuing to dominate the fashion industry. And with so many other early 2000s fashion trends coming back, who knows?</p><p>2020 could be Juicy Couture's year.</p><p><em>EDITOR'S NOTE: This video was originally published in November 2019.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/rise-and-fall-of-juicy-couture-tracksuits-2019-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Ai2RFF3dcQw\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 19:27:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5ddd4badfd9db233183d6e7a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"458ad72297dcbb3f0148f3d460212bec","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-14-005_81c9d83c7270e190.webp","destWidth":1000,"destHeight":750,"sourceBytes":228122,"destBytes":228122,"author":"ikim@businessinsider.com (Irene Anna Kim,Steve Cameron)","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn44@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-24-973_8b7926acbf73e246.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn36@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-20-058_e46d8bf0706a2de0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ai2RFF3dcQw:RJmQni6v_CE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn60@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-21-895_3f81a6ad1c37ccd3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Ai2RFF3dcQw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn16@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-23-931_36cbc5f8093d2b9a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473328},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"The US is betting on 3 types of coronavirus vaccines, one of which is totally unproven. A diagram shows how they differ.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/leading-us-coronavirus-vaccines-how-they-work-compare-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f62484d323fc4001e0d6a37?format=jpeg\" alt=\"covid vaccine\" height=\"2513\" width=\"3770\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A syringe carrying a vaccine.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carol Smiljan/NurPhoto via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Trump administration is backing six coronavirus vaccine candidates as part of Operation Warp Speed.</li>\n<li>Each vaccine targets the virus' spike protein, which helps it attach to and invade cells. But they use three different technological approaches in order to do that.</li>\n<li>The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-vaccine-timeline-what-to-watch-leading-research-2020-3\">leading two candidates, from Moderna and Pfizer</a>, are mRNA vaccines. The others are&#160;protein-based or viral vector vaccines. The chart below shows the difference.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>When we get a flu shot, we don't think about the 10-plus years of work that made it possible to inject that syringe into our arm. But the coronavirus pandemic has catapulted the vaccine-development process into the global spotlight, with people around the world tuned into the race between pharmaceutical companies.&#160;&#160;</p><p>That attention has also has brought up questions about how vaccines actually work.</p><p>None of the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-vaccine-timeline-what-to-watch-leading-research-2020-3\">leading vaccine candidates in the US</a> inject the actual virus, SARS-CoV-2, into the body, contrary to popular myth. Instead, they all rely on a harmless segment of the virus to spur the production of antibodies — Y-shaped proteins that ward off infection.</p><p>\"Your immune system is like an antibody factory,\" Dr. Francis Collins, director of the National Institutes of Health, said at a Senate hearing last month. He added:&#160;\"If at some time in the future, the actual virus enters your body, your factory can quickly pull out the blueprints and ramp up production, wiping up that virus before it has a chance to multiply and make you sick.\"</p><p>Vaccines kickstart that antibody factory in people who haven't been exposed to the virus. But there are various ways to do that. The six candidates backed by Operation Warp Speed — the Trump administration's effort to develop, manufacture, and distribute a coronavirus vaccine — rely on three different technologies to stimulate an immune response.</p><p>Two candidates, from Novavax and a Sanofi-GlaxoSmithKline partnership, inject a protein found on the surface of the coronavirus directly into the body. Another two, from AstraZeneca and Johnson &#38; Johnson, introduce a coronavirus gene to the body using a genetically engineered common-cold virus. The final two candidates, from Moderna and Pfizer, use a snippet of the coronavirus' genome to encourage antibody production.</p><p>Here's a rundown of the differences between the three types of vaccines:</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6e276aa5fb5800198b2e98?format=jpeg\" alt=\"three types of coronavirus vaccines in development infographic\" height=\"1219\" width=\"1667\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shayanne Gal/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>Protein-based vaccine: the slower, traditional method</h2><p>When scientists were developing the hepatitis B vaccine in the 1980s, they discovered that they could grow that virus' surface protein in the lab. Researchers are now attempting to do something similar with the coronavirus.</p><p>The virus consists of four structural proteins, one of which is a spike protein that helps it attach to and invade human cells. A person infected with the coronavirus naturally develops antibodies that neutralize this spike protein, so some vaccines try to mimic that effect.</p><p>Both Novavax and Sanofi-GSK are developing vaccines using a synthesized version of the spike protein, which they grow in insect cells. The protein is then purified and injected into the body. Collins said that process is \"tried and true,\" but it's a bit slower than the technologies used by other candidates.</p><p>Novavax and Sanofi-GSK haven't started phase-three US trials on their protein-based vaccines yet. The former plans to begin a global phase-three study in October, while Sanofi-GSK hopes to start its phase-three trial in December.</p><p>Both vaccines require an adjuvant, a chemical agent that boosts the immune response. This can sometimes cause pain or swelling at the injection site. But the shots' advantage is that they could be stored at regular refrigerator temperature, making them easier to ship than some other leading candidates.</p><h2>Viral vector vaccine: the hearty immune response</h2><p>Instead of directly injecting the spike protein into the body, vector vaccines rely on a middleman: a less harmful class of virus called an adenovirus, which can cause the common cold. Researchers attach a gene for the spike protein to the back of an adenovirus, which then acts as a delivery truck to drop that gene off inside the body. The adenovirus is disabled before it's injected, so it won't replicate inside the body.</p><p>The process triggers the production of the actual spike protein, which our body recognizes as a foreign invader. That leads the immune system to produce antibodies to neutralize it.&#160;</p><p>This approach isn't new — it dates back to the 1980s — but only one viral vector vaccine has been ever been licensed for human use: Sanofi's Dengue vaccine.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f762e6a74fe5b0018a8e908?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Johnson &#38; Johnson coronavirus vaccine clinical trial, volunteer dosed with experimental COVID-19 vaccine\" height=\"4016\" width=\"6016\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A volunteer participates in Johnson &#38; Johnson&#39;s coronavirus vaccine trial.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Janssen</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>One advantage of a vector vaccine is that it can produce a robust immune response without an adjuvant. But developers must strike a careful balance: The vaccine dose should be high enough to induce an immune response, but low enough that the body doesn't overreact with aggressive inflammation.</p><p>The adenovirus used also can't be common, since people with prior exposure would fight it off before it could deliver the spike protein gene. (AstraZeneca's vaccine uses a chimpanzee adenovirus to alleviate that problem.)&#160;</p><p>Though the technology has shown promise, the two leading developers of coronavirus vector vaccines — AstraZeneca and Johnson &#38; Johnson — have both <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-vaccine-timeline-what-to-watch-leading-research-2020-3\">put their US trials on hold</a> to investigate unexplained illnesses in participants. If approved, AstraZeneca's vaccine would require two shots, taken four weeks apart. Johnson &#38; Johnson is testing one shot at the moment, but the company's chief scientific officer, Paul Stoffels, has said <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-johnson-johnson/jj-kicks-off-study-of-single-shot-covid-19-vaccine-in-60000-volunteers-idUSKCN26E27Q\">a second dose could be administered</a> down the line.</p><p>The vector approach may pose challenges for booster shots, though, since the body may recognize the adenovirus and attack it right away.&#160;</p><h2>mRNA vaccine: the new kid on the block</h2><p>RNA vaccines are often referred to as \"the vaccines of the future,\" since the technology is fairly new; early clinical results were <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6446947/\">just starting to emerge</a> before the pandemic. No vaccine using this technology has ever been approved for human use. But now, RNA vaccines are poised to become the first coronavirus shots on the market.</p><p>Moderna and Pfizer's phase-three human trials are currently neck-and-neck. Pfizer hopes to show that its vaccine is effective by the end of this month. Moderna has pinpointed November as the most likely release date for its results.&#160;</p><p>Both vaccines use a small piece of messenger RNA (mRNA) from the coronavirus genome to deliver a gene for the spike protein into the body. The RNA is encased in a lipid molecule that carries it across a cell membrane. From there, it sends a coded message to the body to produce the spike protein.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f1ef660f34d05246811c757?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Nurse Kath Olmstead, right, gives volunteer Melissa Harting, of Harpersville, N.Y., an injection as the world&#39;s biggest study of a possible COVID-19 vaccine, developed by the National Institutes of Health and Moderna Inc., gets underway Monday, July 27, 2020, in Binghamton, N.Y.\" height=\"2991\" width=\"4119\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Nurse Kath Olmstead gives volunteer Melissa Harting an injection of Moderna&#39;s coronavirus vaccine in Binghamton, New York, on July 27.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Hans Pennink</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Unlike vector or protein-based vaccines, mRNA vaccines stimulate the production of killer T cells, which stop the coronavirus from replicating. Another advantage is that mRNA can't cause an infection on its own — though that doesn't mean the vaccine won't have side effects.</p><p>Since the body breaks down mRNA quickly, these vaccines may require a booster shot. Participants in Moderna's trial are receiving two shots 28 days apart. Pfizer is delivering two shots three weeks apart.</p><p>Because mRNA vaccines are grown in test tubes or tanks instead of cells, they should be relatively easy and quick to produce. But there are challenges when delivering and storing them: Pfizer's vaccine needs to be shipped at -94 degrees Fahrenheit and Moderna's at -4 degrees Fahrenheit. In Pfizer's case, that would require vaccination sites to have deep freezers or dry ice on hand.</p><h2>More reliable than a flu vaccine</h2><p>A coronavirus vaccine needs to be at least 50% effective to get emergency authorization from the Food and Drug Administration. But experts hope for better than that: Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said he would \"settle\" for a vaccine that's 70% to 75% effective. That may be enough to achieve herd immunity in the US if everyone gets a shot.</p><p>\"The best we've ever done is measles, which is 97% to 98% effective,\" Fauci <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/28/health/fauci-coronavirus-vaccine-contact-tracing-aspen/index.html\">told CNN</a> in June. \"That would be wonderful if we get there. I don't think we will.\"</p><p>Experts anticipate that the coronavirus vaccine will at the very least be more reliable than the yearly flu vaccine, which was <a href=\"https://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/932995#:~:text=The%20influenza%20vaccine%20was%2039,a%20meeting%20of%20the%20Advisory\">39% effective</a> this past flu season.</p><p>\"If I had to guess, I would say this is probably a better virus for a vaccine to really work well than the influenza virus, which is a tough one because it's changing every year,\" Collins said.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-not-mutating-to-spread-genetics-show-2020-9\">coronavirus mutates far more slowly</a> than the flu, so researchers think a vaccine will remain effective over a longer time.</p><p>In total, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-vaccine-timeline-what-to-watch-leading-research-2020-3\">193 coronavirus vaccine research projects</a> are in progress worldwide.</p><p>\"Having this mix of strategies is the best insurance against some unexpected problem with safety or efficacy,\" Collins said. \"We hope and expect that more than one of these will succeed.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Bendix)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f62484d323fc4001e0d6a37?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn71@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-643_f95ce2e7d86ecb7a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f6e276aa5fb5800198b2e98?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn72@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-17-811_676b349e92073dd1.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f762e6a74fe5b0018a8e908?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn12@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-14-588_10a520e2da386fda.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f1ef660f34d05246811c757?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn100@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-18-935_a8e42e01d6eea03e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vcWw_rbdvCs:vwPaOWbxuPc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn84@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-22-938_8a3d6bbb33285f26.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vcWw_rbdvCs:vwPaOWbxuPc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn91@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-19-588_9cf7a90b02c6ae22.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vcWw_rbdvCs:vwPaOWbxuPc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn88@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-22-070_20ad96c73597e4c0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/vcWw_rbdvCs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn87@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-23-745_daad0612f703e2ce.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473358},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"Space-station crew members just found an elusive air leak by watching tea leaves float in microgravity","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/astronauts-cosmonauts-found-space-station-leak-using-tea-leaves-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8ddda69e9fe4001900a2af?format=jpeg\" alt=\"NASA International Space Station\" height=\"1800\" width=\"2400\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The International Space Station has been leaking an unusual amount of air for more than a year.&#160;</li>\n<li>A cosmonaut finally found the leak by releasing tea leaves to float freely in the station's Russian side. He saw them cluster near a crack on the wall.&#160;</li>\n<li>The crew has temporarily patched the leak with tape, but it may not hold for long.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The International Space Station has been leaking an unusual amount of air since September 2019.</p><p>At first, crew members held off on troubleshooting the issue, since the leak <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-narrows-source-of-leak-on-space-station-2-areas-2020-9\">wasn't major</a>. But in August, the leak rate increased, prompting astronauts and cosmonauts on board the orbiting laboratory to start trying to locate its source in earnest.</p><p>Roscosmos, Russia's space agency, <a href=\"https://tass.com/science/1212465#:~:text=Russian%20cosmonauts%20trace%20air%20leak%20aboard%20orbital%20outpost%20with%20tea%20bag,-The%20tea%20bag's&text=MOSCOW%2C%20October%2015.&text=As%20Russia's%20State%20Space%20Corporation,the%20crew's%20life%20and%20health.0health.\">announced</a> on Thursday that crew members had finally pinpointed the leak's location after devising an unusual test: They let tea leaves guide their search.&#160;&#160;</p><p>Cosmonaut Anatoly Ivanishin released a few leaves from a tea bag in the transfer chamber of the Zvezda Service Module – the section of the station's Russian segment that houses a kitchen, sleeping quarters, and bathroom. Then the crew sealed the chamber off by closing its hatches, and monitored the tea leaves on video cameras as they floated in microgravity.</p><p>The leaves slowly floated toward a scratch in the wall near the module's communication equipment – evidence that it was a crack through which air was escaping.</p><p>The crew has since patched the leak using <a href=\"https://www.vesti.ru/article/2474302?utm_source=yxnews&utm_medium=mobilebile\">Kapton tape</a>, Roscosmos <a href=\"https://twitter.com/roscosmos/status/1318116197016227840\">reported on Monday</a>.</p><h2>A year-long air leak on the space station</h2><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4ebe95e6ff30001d4e67f4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"astronauts\" height=\"867\" width=\"1300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Expedition 63 crew members from left: Chris Cassidy, Anatoly Ivanishin, and Ivan Vagner.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><p>The International Space Station&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/international-space-station-small-air-leak-nasa-says-no-danger-2020-8\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\">always leaks a little air.</a> Normally, resupply missions carry highly pressurized containers full of a mix of oxygen and nitrogen to replace the air the ISS loses. The mix is designed to mimic Earth's breathable air.</p><p>But in September 2019, the standard leak rate increased slightly. That wasn't considered any major risk, but in August 2020, that already elevated rate increased fivefold, from 0.6 to 3.1 pounds of air per day, according to Russian news agency <a href=\"https://ria.ru/20201015/mks-1579976642.html\">Ria Novosti</a>. So over the last two months, crew members <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-roscosmos-found-leak-on-international-space-station-2020-9\">hunted for the leak</a> by isolating sections of the station and monitoring their pressure changes.</p><p>At first, crew members hunkered down in the Zvezda module while they tested the ship's other sections; when they couldn't find evidence of leaks in those sections, they determined the leak was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-narrows-source-of-leak-on-space-station-2-areas-2020-9\">likely in Zvezda itself</a>. Eventually, the astronauts and cosmonauts narrowed the source to Zvezda's transfer chamber. But they still couldn't find the leak's exact location.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f74f56c0ab50d00184ad71d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"transferchamber\" height=\"664\" width=\"1000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Astronaut Jeffrey Ashby moves into the International Space Station&#39;s Zvezda Service Module with a video camera on May 25, 2011.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Then came the tea-leaf trick.</p><p>\"We believe that we have really identified the probable leakage area,\" Ivanishin said, according to <a href=\"https://tass.com/science/1212465#:~:text=Russian%20cosmonauts%20trace%20air%20leak%20aboard%20orbital%20outpost%20with%20tea%20bag,-The%20tea%20bag's&text=MOSCOW%2C%20October%2015.&text=As%20Russia's%20State%20Space%20Corporation,the%20crew's%20life%20and%20health.0health.\">Russian news agency TASS.</a></p><p>The tape the crew put over the crack can remain stable and sticky across a wide range of temperatures, including the near-absolute zero of space. But the members don't think the tape is likely to hold for long; they hope to replace it with a more reliable patch soon.&#160;</p><p>\"Perhaps we should try hard patches our partners have? We can talk with them. This is because the current patch is not so efficient,\" one crew member said, <a href=\"https://tass.com/science/1212945\">according to TASS</a>.</p><p>Roscosmos did not respond to Business Insider's questions in time for publication, but the agency noted in a tweet that it is \"working out a program of operations to permanently seal the leak location.\"</p><p>NASA spokesperson Daniel Huot told Business Insider that the leak \"continues to pose no immediate danger to the crew at the current leak rate.\"&#160;</p><h2><strong>Not the first problem on the space station's Russian side</strong></h2><p>The leak is one of several recent issues on the space station, which is starting to show its age after outlasting its <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/missions/highlights/webcasts/shuttle/sts110/iss-qa.html\">15-year life expectancy</a> by five years.&#160;</p><p>The station's Russian segment houses some of the station's oldest modules. In the last few months, it has seen <a href=\"https://balthazarkorab.com/2020/10/10/toilet-breaks-in-russian-module-on-iss/\">a toilet go bust</a> and temperatures <a href=\"https://www.spacedaily.com/reports/Temperature_Increasing_on_Russian_Zvezda_Module_as_Air_Continues_to_Leak_From_ISS_999.html\">mysteriously increase</a>. Then on Wednesday, the segment's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/international-space-station-oxygen-supply-system-failure-2020-10\">oxygen supply system broke down</a>. Crew members fixed the system by Saturday, according to Roscosmos.</p><p>But in aggregate, the failures are indications that the Russian side of the ISS is probably in need of upgrades.</p><p>\"All modules of the Russian segment are exhausted,\" cosmonaut Gennady Padalka <a href=\"https://ria.ru/20201015/kosmos-1579901308.html\">told Ria Novosti</a>.</p><p>This latest leak also wasn't the first on the Russian side. In August 2018, crew members <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/international-space-station-small-air-leak-nasa-says-no-danger-2020-8\">discovered a 2-millimeter drill hole</a> in part of a Russian Soyuz spaceship that was docked to the station.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4ebe03e6ff30001d4e67f3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"drill hole soyuz\" height=\"562\" width=\"1300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Left: A hole that appears drilled into part of a Soyuz spacecraft at the International Space Station. Right: A patch made by the crew using epoxy.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA via Chris Bergin/Twitter</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The hole seemed to stem from a manufacturing defect; someone on Earth had apparently plugged it with paint, hoping nobody would notice. The paint, it appeared, later broke off. Cosmonauts eventually patched that hole with epoxy sealant.</p><p><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\">Katya Ionova contributed translation assistance for this story.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/astronauts-cosmonauts-found-space-station-leak-using-tea-leaves-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 21:31:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8ddc379e9fe4001900a2a6?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"4392660cf87aa29bcfee2a699bff2e80","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn19@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-12-887_c2a6cc3505b0aef8.webp","destWidth":1778,"destHeight":1334,"sourceBytes":175294,"destBytes":175294,"author":"insider@insider.com (Susie Neilson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8ddda69e9fe4001900a2af?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn99@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-22-378_984a2ad860b0463f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4ebe95e6ff30001d4e67f4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn100@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-21-400_675a0ab66750326b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f74f56c0ab50d00184ad71d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn11@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-23-054_fd069121f385cb62.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4ebe03e6ff30001d4e67f3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn79@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-22-860_cd8123b78cf9cb9b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ERKK9NsLLUA:c7O-RTfEaQE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn52@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-19-401_1ec57d5ab37d4775.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ERKK9NsLLUA:c7O-RTfEaQE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn64@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-20-406_0f217194453bef40.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ERKK9NsLLUA:c7O-RTfEaQE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn4@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-22-214_398b4bdc1b87e47a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ERKK9NsLLUA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn84@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-24-385_ed3dac9d409a5312.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473358},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"Republicans and Democrats are clashing over another stimulus package. Here are 7 areas of disagreement holding up $1,200 checks and coronavirus relief.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/republicans-democrats-stimulus-disagreements-pelosi-trump-mcconnell-aid-bill-differences-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ef710365af6cc4809561c23?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump pelosi\" height=\"750\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Negotiations between the White House and Democrats on another stimulus package are ongoing, but significant differences remain.</li>\n<li>The odds that Congress will enact a federal rescue package with $1,200 stimulus checks before the election appear very low.</li>\n<li>Here's a breakdown of seven differences between both parties on a relief package, including childcare, federal unemployment benefits, overall spending, and testing.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Negotiations between the Trump administration and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi over another coronavirus relief package are crawling along, with few signs of a breakthrough.</p><p>While the White House and Democrats agree on another round of $1,200 stimulus checks for taxpayers, as well as assistance to small businesses and airlines, they've clashed on numerous other measures. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pelosi-says-stimulus-negotiators-have-48-hours-to-reach-agreement-2020-10\">Pelosi said on Sunday</a> that any stimulus deal must be reached by Tuesday so Congress can pass it before the election on November 3.</p><p>The dynamics around a deal are complicated, with many Senate Republicans' opposition to further relief spending as President Donald Trump calls for a large economic rescue package. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcconnell-stimulus-package-coronavirus-relief-compromise-white-house-democrats-2020-10\">suggested on Thursday</a> that he wouldn't put a brokered deal up for a floor vote.</p><p>Here's a breakdown of seven policy disagreements that are holding up another stimulus package.</p><h2>Cost</h2><p>Democrats have insisted on at least $2.2 trillion in additional spending to prop up people, businesses, and public-health agencies. The House <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/house-democrats-stimulus-plan-congress-unemployment-economy-pass-vote-bill-2020-9\">earlier this month</a> passed a slimmed-down version of the $3.4 trillion Heroes Act from May. The latest legislation includes more stimulus checks, among other provisions.</p><p>Meanwhile, the Trump administration made <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-administration-stimulus-plan-direct-payments-unemployment-benefits-2020-10\">a $1.8 trillion offer</a> to Democrats. In recent weeks, the White House has increased the amount it's willing to spend. But it faces significant opposition from Senate Republicans who are reluctant to support a price tag of that size, reducing the odds that a bipartisan deal will become law.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-investing-advice-stimulus-talks-sector-impact-david-bahnsen-2020-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"c9969fa995e68f3a27aefbe8005fad2d\">A $2.5 billion investment chief highlights the stock-market sectors poised to benefit the most if stimulus is passed after the election — and says Trump ending negotiations doesn't threaten the economic recovery</a></em></p><h2>Federal unemployment benefits</h2><p>While both parties agree that the government should supplement state unemployment checks, they're quarreling over the amount.</p><p>Democrats have not moved away from calling for the restoration of the $600 federal weekly unemployment benefit through January. They've argued that unemployment remains high in an economy displaying renewed signs of weakness, such as slowing job growth.</p><p>The Trump administration offered a $400 weekly federal supplement. Some Republicans are still critical, saying it would disincentivize work and set back the economic recovery.</p><h2>Coronavirus testing</h2><p>Pelosi and <a href=\"https://energycommerce.house.gov/newsroom/press-releases/pallone-on-administration-s-covid-19-relief-proposal\">other Democrats</a> have cited the lack of a national coronavirus testing and tracing strategy as a key reason they rejected the administration's offer.</p><p>Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has said that <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-usa-mnuchin/mnuchin-says-still-working-toward-coronavirus-relief-deal-not-hung-up-on-testing-idUSKBN2701TX\">the differences between the sides are \"overblown\"</a> and that the administration would accept the Democratic position with few changes.</p><p>But Democrats dismissed the new legislative language as insufficient and called for bigger changes.</p><h2>Tax credits for low-income Americans</h2><p>As part of their federal rescue package, <a href=\"https://waysandmeans.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/neal-statement-inadequacy-trump-administration-relief-proposal\">Democrats are seeking</a> to widen tax credits for people and families with lower incomes, such as the child tax credit and the <a href=\"https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/briefing-book/what-earned-income-tax-credit\">earned income tax credit</a>.</p><p>The expanded child tax credit would provide a modest monthly payment to people who have smaller incomes or don't earn enough to file taxes.</p><p>The Trump administration's newest plan doesn't include funding to expand either credit, which Democrats have argued is necessary to help struggling families and unemployed people.</p><h2>Aid to states</h2><p>Democrats <a href=\"https://appropriations.house.gov/news/press-releases/lowey-statement-on-trump-administration-s-inadequate-coronavirus-relief-offer\">want to include</a> at least $436 billion in aid to states weathering significant shortfalls in their budgets. Reduced tax revenue has <a href=\"https://www.cbpp.org/blog/states-localities-need-federal-aid-to-restore-jobs-avoid-more-layoffs\">caused 1.2 million public employees</a> to lose their jobs.</p><p>Republicans have derided a \"blue-state bailout,\" saying it would provide funds for states to shore up pensions and use the money for measures unrelated to the pandemic.</p><p>But some Republican governors have also called for federal aid.</p><h2>Childcare</h2><p>Democrats' latest economic aid package <a href=\"https://www.speaker.gov/sites/speaker.house.gov/files/20201012_ChairmanScott_Statement_WhiteHouseCOVID19ReliefProposal.pdf\">includes</a> $57 billion to bolster childcare providers. <a href=\"https://childcarerelief.org/child-care-providers-experiencing-47-increase-in-operating-expenses-amid-pandemic-crisis/\">Advocates have said</a> many are grappling with the loss of revenue and increased operating expenses, forcing many providers to close.</p><p>The administration's plan does include an unspecified amount of funding for childcare. <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/week-transcript-10-18-20-speaker-nancy-pelosi/story?id=73680422\">But Pelosi told ABC News</a> on Sunday it was insufficient and that Democrats would continue pressing for more.</p><h2>Liability protections for businesses</h2><p>Republicans are seeking a liability shield for businesses to protect them from coronavirus-related lawsuits from workers and customers through <a href=\"https://www.cornyn.senate.gov/sites/default/files/SAFETOWORKAct.pdf\">the Safe to Work Act</a>. They say a wave of lawsuits could deter employers from reopening and could harm the economy.</p><p>Democrats lambasted this step as an unacceptable measure, with Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York last month calling it \"a poison pill.\" They've pressed to strengthen workplace protections and safety standards through the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, a federal regulatory agency.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/republicans-democrats-stimulus-disagreements-pelosi-trump-mcconnell-aid-bill-differences-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2020 18:25:06 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8dbee6c21cfb0019468cc0?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"20990b97cf41f81a358c7089c08669bf","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn19@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-13-951_168af1ca7eb6b60f.webp","destWidth":1333,"destHeight":1000,"sourceBytes":103610,"destBytes":103610,"author":"jzeballos@businessinsider.com Zeballos-Roig)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ef710365af6cc4809561c23?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn96@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-18-957_a3a81310ecdef0fc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bXE-FCzFFtM:dAiirpRJfDg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn60@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-15-156_6c52252b97ab8473.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bXE-FCzFFtM:dAiirpRJfDg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn11@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-25-426_a860f8c9b0777211.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bXE-FCzFFtM:dAiirpRJfDg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn55@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-18-465_00dc201b7ea49e2d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/bXE-FCzFFtM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn76@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-17-066_dfb7c4270ddcf514.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473336},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"How to get hired in tech: From Google and Amazon to growing startups, here's everything you need to know to land a tech job","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/ultimate-resource-hub-for-tech-jobseekers-2020-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d6040bc9563f470b6001b82?format=jpeg\" alt=\"work tech office computers\" height=\"1000\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Per-Anders Pettersson/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>The coronavirus pandemic has left millions of people unemployed across a broad spectrum of industries.&#160;</li><li>The tech industry has not been immune, with many startups laying off workers.</li><li>But many tech companies are weathering the storm better than businesses in other industries. And some tech firms — like those that make tools to help people work remotely — are even seeing demand for their products surge.</li><li>Business Insider has compiled some of the best articles we've written about getting a job in tech, whether you want to work at Google or Netflix or a hot new startup.</li><li>Here are some of the key resources to help you find a job in the tech industry, from tips for the interview processes at various companies to information about the tech skills and jobs most in demand, as well as data about the levels of compensation for different roles.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><h2>Identify the bright spots</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5db1ee9ddee01964724bbb23?format=jpeg\" alt=\"woman using laptop\" height=\"1414\" width=\"2121\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Sarah Waiswa/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/future-of-work-startups-success-year-venture-capital-2020-4?r=techjobhub\">30 startups creating the future of work that will prosper in 2020, according to VCs</a></p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/open-source-companies-recession-coronavirus-2020-3?r=techjobhub\">Here's why open source software startups often get stronger in downturns and recessions, according to executives who navigated the Great Recession</a></p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zoom-hiring-increase-support-new-users-lynne-oldham-2020-4?r=techjobhub\">Zoom's surge in popularity means it will blast past its 'extremely ambitious' hiring goals this year. Here are 17 they think will thrive in 2020.</a></p><h2>Company specific resources:&#160;</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5bfc99fd0d7c670a352c1ab7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Google campus\" height=\"2727\" width=\"4091\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Stephen Lam</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h3 style=\"padding-left: 40px;\">Amazon:</h3><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-get-a-job-at-amazon-say-insiders-2020-1?r=techjobhub\">Insiders reveal how to cut through Amazon's ruthless interviewing process to land a job there</a></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-work-at-amazon-first-job-2018-7?r=techjobhub\">An Amazon recruiter says she doesn't expect new grads to be business majors, but demonstrating leadership principles on their resumes makes them stand out</a></p><h3 style=\"padding-left: 40px;\">Apple:</h3><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/former-engineer-postmates-how-to-get-job-at-apple?r=techjobhub\">An engineer who spent 15 years working at Apple shares what it takes to land a role at the tech giant, where engineers are paid over $100,000 a year</a></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biggest-interview-mistakes-job-seekers-make-2017-9?r=techjobhub\">The 2 worst mistakes you could make in a job interview, according to an ex-Apple recruiter</a></p><h3 style=\"padding-left: 40px;\">Netflix:</h3><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-get-a-job-at-netflix-tips-guide-hr-2020-1?r=techjobhub\">The ultimate guide to getting a job at Netflix. and aren't able to back the claim up. Here are 3 qualities she looks for instead.</a></p><h2>&#160;</h2><h2>Upgrade your tech skills</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5da8e5f1cc4a0a7e593bfd88?format=jpeg\" alt=\"working Jobs, Jack Dorsey, and Aaron Sorkin used to spark creative thinking at work</a></p></section><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (Business Insider)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5d6040bc9563f470b6001b82?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn32@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-22-431_505fa0bffc840e0d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5db1ee9ddee01964724bbb23?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-15-569_20e4e91fef4c83d4.webp","https://i.insider.com/5bfc99fd0d7c670a352c1ab7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn96@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-19-800_c6afa103284b977d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5da8e5f1cc4a0a7e593bfd88?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn11@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-22-214_bca651df33fce749.webp","https://i.insider.com/5a285710f914c354018b863b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn96@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-18-049_d6653983c69c86de.webp","https://i.insider.com/5c37855bbd77306ffc7e1605?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn31@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-15-850_9bfab3d7aaa09487.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ogAZSfH6K20:8EXFs4VGHe8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn23@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-22-309_766c192a6ff9f7cb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ogAZSfH6K20:8EXFs4VGHe8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn35@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-18-261_95492d916af45ce6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ogAZSfH6K20:8EXFs4VGHe8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn64@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-24-259_9dfc537e3a77ca8d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ogAZSfH6K20":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn28@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-24-106_195e4e0913075337.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473373},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"Bonds vs. CDs: The key differences and how to decide which income-producing option is better for you","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/bonds-vs-cds","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8df5359e9fe4001900a347?format=jpeg\" alt=\"bonds vs cds\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An investor&#39;s long-term goals, need for cash, and tolerance for risk all play a part in deciding between bonds or CDs.\n<p class=\"copyright\">PeopleImages/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Bonds and CDs (certificates of deposit) are both fixed-interest investments, popular with investors seeking a low-risk income stream.&#160;</li>\n<li>CDs are federally insured and tend to come with relatively short maturity dates. Bonds often have 10-to-30-year terms and may offer tax advantages.</li>\n<li>CDs could be a good fit for short-term investors who don't want to risk losing principal, while bonds may be better for long-term investors or those seeking tax-free income.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\"><strong>Visit Insider's Investing Reference library for more stories</strong></a><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\"><strong>.</strong></a></li>\n</ul><p>If you're looking for investments that can provide a steady income stream, bonds and CDs are two strong choices. While both are likely to underperform riskier investments like dividend stocks or <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/how-to-invest-in-real-estate-make-money\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">real estate</a> in the long-term, they also generally offer more safety and stability.</p><p>Bonds and CDs have a lot in common. But there are times when one may be a better choice than the other.</p><p>It's important to know the differences so that you choose the fixed-income investment that best suits your needs. Here's a rundown of the key features of each, and how to opt for one over the other.&#160;</p><h2>What is a bond?</h2><p>A <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/bonds\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">bond</a> is a loan that investors make to large entities, like governments or companies. In return for borrowing your money, the bond issuer promises to pay a certain interest rate over a set period of time and to repay the principal when the bond reaches maturity.</p><p>Government bonds are considered very safe investments, especially those issued by the United States Treasury. The US federal government has never defaulted on a debt.&#160;</p><p>State and local governments also issue these debt securities, known as municipal bonds. Their riskiness varies, depending on the state or municipality's credit rating.</p><p>Corporate bonds can be riskier than government or municipal bonds, but may also offer more attractive interest rates. To research a bond's degree of risk, you can check its credit grade assigned by credit-rating agencies like Standard and Poor's, Moody's, and Fitch. Like academic grades, they're letters, ranging from A to F. Any bond that gets ranked BBB or above is considered \"investment grade.\"</p><h2>What is a CD?</h2><p>A <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/what-is-a-cd-certificate-of-deposit\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">certificate of deposit (CD)</a> is actually a type of savings account offered by banks. With a CD, you promise to keep your money in the account for a specific period of time (usually from a few months to five years).&#160;</p><p>In exchange, the bank promises to pay a fixed interest rate that is often higher than it offers on its <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/best-high-yield-savings-accounts-rates-right-now\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">traditional savings account</a>. Many CDs make interest payments on a monthly basis, but some banks may choose a different schedule (such as quarterly or semi-annually).</p><p>Many CDs will charge an early withdrawal penalty (EWP) if you take out your money before the account's maturity date. However, some banks do offer no-penalty CD products. And keep in mind that some banks will allow customers to withdraw accrued interest from their CDs without triggering an EWP.</p><h2>Bonds vs. CDs: Key differences</h2><p>From a strategic standpoint, what main features differentiate bonds and CDs?&#160;</p><p><strong>1. Bonds trade on markets, CDs don't.</strong><strong>&#160;</strong>While investors can choose to hold their bonds until maturity, many can also be sold beforehand on the secondary market. As a general rule, bond prices have an inverse relationship with interest rates. So when interest rates go down, bond prices tend to go up (and vice versa).</p><p><strong>2. CDs are insured, bonds are not.</strong>&#160;CDs come with FDIC insurance of up to $250,000 per account-holder. And credit unions, which offer their own version of CDs called \"share certificates,\" also carry $250,000 of federal insurance via the National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund.</p><p>Municipal and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/corporate-bond-sales-reach-trillion-fastest-pace-ever-debt-market-2020-5-1029258342\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">corporate bonds</a> don't come with this kind of federal insurance protection. So if you lend money to a company that later finds itself in financial straits, it may be unable to fulfill its debt obligations.</p><p>This means that some bonds are riskier investments than CDs. However, it should be noted that Treasury bonds are backed by the same federal government that funds the FDIC (Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation). For this reason, federal bonds and CDs carry virtually the same (very low) level of risk.</p><p><strong>3. Bonds are often tax-advantaged, CDs are not.</strong>&#160;CD income is generally taxed as normal income. So, if you happen to be in the 24% <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/what-tax-bracket-am-i-in-federal-income-tax\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">tax bracket</a>, you'd need to pay $24 in taxes for every $100 of CD interest payments you accrue.</p><p>However, bonds issued by the government often come with tax advantages. For example, Treasury bond investors are only required to pay federal taxes on their interest payments, but not state. The exemption from local taxes could provide significant savings for investors who live in high income-tax states.</p><p>Municipal bonds come with great tax-saving benefits too. Income from these bonds is completely exempt from federal taxes and may be excluded from state and local taxes as well (if you buy one from the state you reside and file in).&#160;</p><p><strong>4. CDs typically have shorter maturity dates.</strong>&#160;Many bonds have long-term maturity dates of 10 years or more. For example, Treasury bonds mature in 20 to 30 years. Meanwhile, CDs usually mature within 5 years, with a few banks offering longer CDs of up to 10 years.</p><h2>When to consider CDs</h2><p>Although it isn't necessarily an either/or, CDs have benefits over bonds if:</p><h3>You think that interest rates will soon go up</h3><p>Compared to traditional savings accounts, CDs are not a great place to have your money stashed in an increasing interest-rate environment. Savings accounts can raise their rates at any time, while your <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/who-has-the-best-cd-rates-right-now\">CD rates</a> won't change after account opening.</p><bi-shortcode id=\"related-article-module\" class=\"mceNonEditable\" data-type=\"5dd312be3afd37342b479224\" data-title=\"The best CD rates of October 2020\" data-url=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/who-has-the-best-cd-rates-right-now\" data-thumbnail=\"https://i.insider.com/5dde8f85fd9db257724a8fd4\" data-shortcode-display-text=\"Related Article Module: The best CD rates of October 2020\">&#160;</bi-shortcode><p>But CDs are actually a <em>safer</em> bet than bonds when interest rates are going up. Why? Because the yield for bonds trading on the secondary financial markets will decrease as interest rates rise. But since CDs aren't traded on markets, their yields aren't diminished by rising rates.&#160;</p><p>If you expect rates to rise, buying <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/best-1-year-cd-rates\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">short-term CDs </a>for the foreseeable future may be the way to go. In this way, you can lock in your current yield while also giving yourself the flexibility to open new (and, hopefully, higher-yield) CDs each time an account reaches maturity.</p><h3>You don't want to risk losing any principal</h3><p>With a CD, it's highly unlikely that you will lose any of your initial investment. Even if you have to pay an early withdrawal penalty (EWP), the fee is typically calculated as a portion of the interest that you would have accrued over a certain period of time. Depending on how long you've held the account, that forfeiture of interest may not cut into your principal at all.</p><p>Selling bonds before their maturity date, on the other hand, can be trickier. If the current interest rates being offered on bonds are higher than what yours pays, you'll need to sell yours at a discount in order to attract a buyer. If you want complete protection from this kind of volatility, opening a CD account will be your better option.</p><h3>You have a short-term investment horizon</h3><p>It's true that there are some short-term bonds that come with durations of one to four years. But if you expect to withdraw your money that quickly, a CD may be the simpler investment vehicle. Plus, with a CD, you won't have to worry about incurring any trade transaction costs.&#160;</p><h2>When to consider bonds</h2><p>Bonds might be a better play if:</p><h3>You think that think interest rates will soon go down</h3><p>In a decreasing interest rate environment, bond yields typically increase. So if you feel like rates are primed to fall, choosing bonds over CDs could be a smart choice.</p><p>However, it should be noted that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fed-interest-rate-cut-zero-bond-holdings-coronavirus-pandemic-economy-2020-3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">in March 2020 the Federal Reserve sets its benchmark interest rate at 0% to 0.25%</a> to provide economic relief during the COVID-19 pandemic.&#160;</p><p>As a result, interest rates across a variety of banking products have hit all-time lows. With this in mind, interest rates (in the short-term) are more likely to stagnate or move up than suffer any type of precipitous fall.</p><h3>You prize liquidity</h3><p>Unlike CDs, you're never locked in with bonds — you can sell at any time, should your goals or needs change. Depending on where prevailing interest rates are, you could even sell it at a premium, realizing a nice little capital gain.&#160;</p><h3>You want to minimize the taxes you pay on your investment income</h3><p>Due to their tax advantages, federal and municipal bonds will leave you with more money in your pocket than a CD offering the exact same interest rate.&#160;</p><p>The difference will be most pronounced for investors in high tax brackets. Be sure to calculate the after-tax returns of bonds and CDs when comparing your options.</p><h3>You have a long-term investment horizon</h3><p>With many bonds having maturity dates of 10 to 30 years, they can be a great \"set it and forget it\" option for long-term investors who want to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-invest-in-bonds-generate-returns-hedge-stock-market-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">protect themselves against stock market volatility</a>.</p><p>For instance, a 30-year old investor may choose a 70/30 (70% stocks/30% bonds) <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-investing-strategy-asset-allocation-coronavirus-crisis-sebastien-page-2020-5\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">asset allocation</a> for their investment portfolio. While this investor could technically continue buying new CDs every 5 to 10 years to provide a similar cushion against market volatility, that would take a lot more work.&#160;</p><p>Plus, investing in bonds over CD is simpler if you're looking to keep all of your retirement funds in the same <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-401k\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">401(k)</a> or <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/what-is-a-traditional-ira\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">IRA account</a>.&#160;</p><h2>The financial takeaway</h2><p>Whether you're looking to increase your savings yield or hedge against stock market volatility, both bonds and CDs can be valuable additions to a diversified portfolio. But each has its own advantages and disadvantages. To decide which is right for you, you'll need to consider your income needs, investment time horizon, and your opinion about the future direction of interest rates.</p><p>If you decide that bonds are a better fit for your situation, investing in a diversified bond mutual fund or ETF could be an easy way to start. And if you decide to go with a CD, make sure to shop around for the best rates available, as they can and do vary among banks.</p><h2>Related Coverage in&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">Investing</a>:</h2><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-are-junk-bonds\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">What are junk bonds? A risky yet high-yield investment that can bring rewards if you're willing to take the chance</a></h3><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-an-etn\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-position=\"15\" data-analytics-module=\"\">ETNs combine a bond's reliability with a stock's profitability. Here's how they work, and how to weigh the risks and rewards</a></h3><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/are-cds-a-good-investment\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-position=\"34\" data-analytics-module=\"\">If you've ever considered putting money in a CD, now is probably the right time to do it</a></h3><h3><a
