+0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8dddc49e9fe4001900a2b1?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"05d10e6b3b9227af10c4649e62bfa87f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn32@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-13-927_a606bd000370491a.webp","destWidth":4530,"destHeight":3398,"sourceBytes":374030,"destBytes":374030,"author":"insider@insider.com (Allana Akhtar)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8dde3c9e9fe4001900a2b8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn91@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-25-246_04137323191dbe44.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uzz5Ty-Dy6k:AjbPKYouSMI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn83@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-14-209_896bde38ce0d4e43.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uzz5Ty-Dy6k:AjbPKYouSMI:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn84@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-16-993_04d8ba298c80ee41.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uzz5Ty-Dy6k:AjbPKYouSMI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn3@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-14-264_3770994f318397d9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/uzz5Ty-Dy6k":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn39@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-15-865_6ea9f2e98392bf4f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473331},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"The Army wants a new high-powered grenade launcher to blast drones out of the air","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/army-wants-new-high-powered-grenade-launcher-for-drones-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8dea0d9e9fe4001900a2fa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"M320 grenade launcher\" height=\"900\" width=\"1800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A soldier with an M320 grenade launcher.\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Army</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Army is looking for a new \"Precision Grenadier System,\" with \"increased lethality and precision.\"</li>\n<li>The service also envisions new ammunition, including rounds designed to counter \"light armored targets\" and \"hovering [unmanned aerial system] targets.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Soldiers can prepare to kiss their standard-issue M203 and M320s goodbye: The Army is officially on the hunt for a brand new grenade launcher.</p><p>Army Contracting Command on Thursday issued a <a href=\"https://beta.sam.gov/opp/94c888ff87544fdf9df499cd357f1104/view?index=opp&psc=10&page=2p;page=2\" target=\"_blank\" onclick=\"return phoenixTrackClickEvent(this, event);\" rel=\"noopener\">source sought notice</a> on behalf of Product Manager Individual Weapons in search of a new \"Precision Grenadier System,\" or PGS, with \"increased lethality and precision\" compared to legacy 40 mm systems.</p><p>The ideal PGS is described as \"a man-portable integrated weapon system that enables precision engagements to destroy personnel targets in defilade and in the open,\" according to the notice, with the system capable of engaging targets at ranges between 500 and 1,000 meters.</p><p>Based on the specifications detailed in the notice, the proposed PGS system will be significantly larger than the now-standard M320 (which is 11.8 inches and 5 pounds), measuring and weighing a maximum of 34 inches and 14.5 pounds, <a href=\"https://armypubs.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/pdf/web/tm3_22x31.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" onclick=\"return phoenixTrackClickEvent(this, event);\" rel=\"noopener\">according</a> to Army documents.</p><p>What's truly distinctive about the proposed PGS, however, is the choice in ammo: The system envisions a suite of ammo beyond those typically used to engage targets in cover, including rounds specially designed to counter \"light armored targets\" and \"hovering [unmanned aerial system] targets,\" according to the notice.</p><p>Indeed, the armor-piercing rounds should be capable of nailing a lightly armored vehicle at a minimum distance of 500 meters \"with an armor penetration of between 1.0 to 2.0 inches at 90 degrees rolled homogenous armor,\" <a href=\"https://beta.sam.gov/opp/94c888ff87544fdf9df499cd357f1104/view?index=opp&psc=10&page=2p;page=2\" target=\"_blank\" onclick=\"return phoenixTrackClickEvent(this, event);\" rel=\"noopener\">according</a> to the notice.</p><p>In terms of taking our enemy drones, the counter-UAS round should be \"capable of defeating small UAS systems out to 300 meters,\" according to the <a href=\"https://beta.sam.gov/opp/94c888ff87544fdf9df499cd357f1104/view?index=opp&psc=10&page=2p;page=2\" target=\"_blank\" onclick=\"return phoenixTrackClickEvent(this, event);\" rel=\"noopener\">notice</a>.</p><p>The Army first began fielding the M320 in 2009 before later upgrading to the M320A1 that mounts under the M4 carbine, <a href=\"https://www.military.com/daily-news/2019/04/03/marine-corps-finally-fielding-new-40mm-grenade-launcher.html\" target=\"_blank\" onclick=\"return phoenixTrackClickEvent(this, event);\" rel=\"noopener\">per</a> Military.com. According to Army budget documents, the service has spent more than $270 million on more than 45,000 M320 systems and accessories since then.</p><p>At the moment, a timeline for testing and fielding a proposed new grenade launcher is unclear: the sources sought notice does not constitute a formal request for proposal. PEO Soldier did not immediately respond to requests for comment from Task &#38; Purpose.</p><p>One thing is likely, though: Whenever the Army <em>does</em> adopt the new PGS, <a href=\"https://taskandpurpose.com/military-tech/marine-corps-m320-grenade-launcher\">it'll take the Marine Corps at least a decade to finally get their hands on it</a> — <a href=\"https://taskandpurpose.com/military-tech/marine-corps-m320-grenade-launcher\">and you'll probably get a chance to rock the new system in \"Battlefield\" before then</a>.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/army-wants-new-high-powered-grenade-launcher-for-drones-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=DSbXE_jyYQA:uXJJHXxC4a8:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=DSbXE_jyYQA:uXJJHXxC4a8:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/DSbXE_jyYQA\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 19:54:08 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8dedfc9e9fe4001900a30b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"8d38211f731b344a90aa0ec9aea3eaa6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn99@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-13-861_205a867d521bcc13.webp","destWidth":1594,"destHeight":1196,"sourceBytes":121574,"destBytes":121574,"author":"insider@insider.com (Jared Keller)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8dea0d9e9fe4001900a2fa?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn23@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-24-172_5989f71c5628e9d3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=DSbXE_jyYQA:uXJJHXxC4a8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn87@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-16-974_25aea7511de801d2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=DSbXE_jyYQA:uXJJHXxC4a8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn60@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-12-886_4f4da962031110af.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=DSbXE_jyYQA:uXJJHXxC4a8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn40@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-22-620_68403ccb66171604.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/DSbXE_jyYQA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn7@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-981_e7891c186cb0e97c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473320},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"Why plane tires don't explode during landing","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-plane-tires-dont-explode-during-landing-2019-10","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/29RjO2XK-jZbcmOYf.html\"\nwidth=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"auto\" title=\"Why plane tires don't explode during landing\"\nstyle=\"position:absolute;\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Plane tires can handle thousands of pounds of weight and high speeds &#8212; and it's mostly due to how they're made.&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li>A combination of sturdy materials and nitrogen create a tire strong enough to handle the rigorous conditions upon landing.&#160;</li>\n<li>Goodyear, one of the leading manufacturers of plane tires, gave Business Insider a look into its factory to see how it ensures tires are up to its standards.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.</a></li>\n</ul><p><em>Following is a transcript of the video.</em></p><p><strong>Narrator</strong>: If you dropped a watermelon at 170 mph, it would be a mess. Strap over 500,000 pounds to its back and it would be, well, nothing.</p><p>But airplane tires manage that impact every day, without incident. They're made to withstand hitting the pavement at extreme speeds, all while supporting an entire commercial jet. Don't think too hard about it next time you're in the air, but 45 inches of rubber is the only thing standing between you and the tarmac during landing.</p><p>So, what makes them tough enough for the job?</p><p>If you've ever driven down a US highway, you've probably seen shredded tires along the way. Semitruck tires aren't supposed to explode, but they do. Airplane tires? Not so much. There are a few differences between the two.</p><p>First of all, a semitruck isn't falling out of the sky as part of its route. Those tires don't need to be made to withstand the same high speeds and weights. Airplane tires, on the other hand, need to be reinforced.</p><p><strong>Brandy Moorhead</strong>: They're made with a combination of proprietary synthetic rubber compounds, which are paired with aluminum steel reinforcements and nylon and aramid fabrics.</p><p><strong>Narrator</strong>: That's Brandy. She's in charge of Goodyear's aircraft tires, and she told us that airplane tires are inflated twice as much as truck tires and six times as much as a car's. That's because the higher the pressure, the firmer the tire, and the more strength it has to support the plane. And when they're inflated, it's not with regular air. Airplane tires are filled with nitrogen.</p><p><strong>Brandy</strong>: Nitrogen is an inert gas, so high temperatures and pressure changes have less effect.</p><p><strong>Narrator</strong>: Plane tires are subjected to the most rigorous conditions of any vehicle tire. When Goodyear develops a new airplane tire, it starts with a prototype. Then the tires are tested beyond their breaking points. They're tested for speed, pressure, and the ability to handle a load up to 38 tons. So they have to be made very differently than other tires. Instead of the blocky design seen on a lot of car tires, plane tires get groovy.</p><p><strong>Brandy</strong>: That blocked pattern enables different maneuvering and different characteristics of ride and handling, which are required by an automobile, as opposed to just an aircraft that takes off and lands on a runway. The reason we have grooves in an aircraft tire at all is because we need to evacuate water if we were to land on a wet surface.</p><p><strong>Narrator</strong>: Commercial jets usually have around 20 tires and touch down about 500 times before they have to be retread, which can be done seven times before the tire's no better than scrap rubber. And tires at the nose of the plane tend to have shorter life spans than the rest.</p><p>It takes two mechanics up to an hour to change a single tire. They raise the tire only 5 centimeters off the ground, which doesn't feel like enough room to fit a thumb, let alone change a plane tire. The mechanics take off the hubcap and reduce the tire pressure from 200 to 30 psi, which reduces the risk of it exploding as the bolts and nuts holding it on the plane are removed. A sleeve protects the axle, and a lifting tool pulls the tire off. The axle sleeve is then greased, and the new tire is slid smoothly on. And then things move in reverse: nuts and bolts, tire reinflated to 200, hubcap back on, and the whole thing is gently lowered 5 centimeters back onto the ground.</p><p>So, what happens after 500 landings, seven retreadings, and uncountable \"This is your captain speaking\"s? A lot of the tires get recycled into playground mulch and even other tires for farming equipment. Those tires will be made from old plane tires, but not like them. There's no need. Because if a farmer is using their tractor the same way they'd use a plane, well, they're doing it wrong.</p><p><em>EDITOR'S NOTE: This video was originally published in October 2019.</em></p><div earbuds","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/headphone-deals","description":"<p class=\"financial-disclaimer\"><i>When you buy through our links, we may earn money from our affiliate partners. <a Beoplay E8\" height=\"599\" width=\"799\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li><strong>Good-quality headphones can be expensive, but they often go on sale.</strong></li><li><strong>We've rounded up the best headphone deals for October 2020.</strong></li><li><strong>We'll update this list regularly with the top that's</strong><strong> $70 off their regular price.</strong></li></ul><p>A great pair of headphones can change the way you listen to music. Sure, the random earbuds that you have in your bottom drawer may do the job just fine for some, but if you want to hear nuanced details, well-rounded bass, or a sparkling high-end, you'll need something a little more versatile.</p><p>If you are in the market for a new pair of headphones, it's worth figuring out exactly what kind of headphones you want. The first step is to determine whether you want in-ear headphones, on-ear headphones, or over-ear headphones.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-earbuds\">In-ear headphones</a> are more portable than any other headphones, while <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-over-ear-headphones\">over-ear headphones</a> are the most comfortable and deep-sounding. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-on-ear-headphones\">On-ear headphones</a> are often considered a good compromise between the two. If you hate wires, you could also get <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-wireless-earbuds\">true wireless in-ear headphones</a>, like AirPods, which cut the cables completely.&#160;</p><p>It's also worth looking into a few headphone brands. If you're an audiophile who wants the best-sounding headphones, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sennheiser-hd1-wireless-headphones-deal-amazon-2019-9\">companies like Sennheiser</a>, Klipsch, and Shure are worth considering. If you want incredible noise-cancelling headphones or those that work great for day-to-day use, consider those from Sony or <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bose-700-wireless-noise-cancelling-headphones-review-nearly-perfect-2019-7\">Bose</a>. And, if you want plenty of bass and tight integration with your Apple products, look into <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/beats-solo-pro-headphones-review-great-sound-not-comfortable-2019-10\">headphones from Beats</a> or Apple itself.</p><p>Once you've determined the type of headphones you want, you'll want to figure out what your budget is. These days, you can get solid headphones for under $100, but as with anything, you get what you pay for — and the more you're willing to spend, the better headphones you'll be able to get.&#160;</p><p>Of course, you don't necessarily have to spend as much as you normally would if you can find a great deal. They also boast long battery lives and plenty of padding for a comfortable fit. Some models even include smart features &#8212; like integration with your digital assistant, noise cancellation, and more.</p><p>Right now, the best deal available is on the <a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/deeplink?id=EHFxW6yx8Uo&#38;mid=44583&#38;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newegg.com%2Fblack-sony-wh-1000xm3-b-headphone%2Fp%2F0TH-000U-008U8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Sony WH1000XM3</a>, which are just $240 on Newegg. Sure, you won't be able to fit them in your pocket, but they're light-weight enough to easily carry around in a bag or backpack without noticing much of a difference. Unlike over-ear headphones, on-ear headphones rest on your outer ear, but good ones don't do so uncomfortably.</p><p>The best deal on on-ear headphones right now is for the <a href=\"https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&#38;u=1088116&#38;m=62772&#38;urllink=www.dailysteals.com%2Fproducts%2Fbeats-solo3-club-collection-wireless-on-ear-headphones\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Beats Solo3 Wireless Club Collection headphones</a>, which are around $97 off when you use the code BISOLO at checkout. In-ear headphones are the way to go. +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8e09f49e9fe4001900a3c9?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"6b4146068c5ffd8dc0873dc7a37b97f8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn16@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-07-171_85df0f4a8caddb68.webp","destWidth":799,"destHeight":599,"sourceBytes":39510,"destBytes":39510,"author":"insider@insider.com (Christian de Looper)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8e09f49e9fe4001900a3c9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn16@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-07-171_85df0f4a8caddb68.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ecfcd9d5af6cc7e461e2676?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn57@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-17-883_d45c28f1cf1edd48.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ec2fc294dca6812c3118dd1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn44@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-23-547_60833ac9046bca1c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f32b76c7924a135331be15a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn72@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-20-281_318ce4dc0eb7537f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e7d0929671de0362706da9e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn19@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-20-109_420d3b9ee27bd44d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vHWW1-w1kmo:L8Z5vbTXWas:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn68@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-25-092_e7f9c05164868e85.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vHWW1-w1kmo:L8Z5vbTXWas:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn24@2020_5/2020/10/20/02-05-15-568_0e46bf8ff3070137.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vHWW1-w1kmo:L8Z5vbTXWas:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn95@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-16-289_c6b5e5a81f204681.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/vHWW1-w1kmo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn48@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-15-051_280d1e227f42c773.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473315},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"Trump reportedly slammed Anthony Fauci as 'a disaster' on a campaign phone call","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/anthony-fauci-donald-trump-coronavirus-restrictions-election-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8db6999e9fe4001900a18e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Fauci-1\" height=\"2400\" width=\"3199\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dr. Anthony Fauci.\n<p class=\"copyright\">GRAEME JENNINGS/POOL/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>President Donald Trump blasted Dr. Anthony Fauci, the US's top infectious-disease expert, as a \"disaster\" in a campaign phone call on Monday, CNN reported.</li>\n<li>\"If I listened to him, we'd have 500,000 deaths,\" Trump reportedly said, adding: \"People are saying whatever. Just leave us alone.\"</li>\n<li>As part of the White House's coronavirus task force, Fauci has been one of the most visible faces for Americans during the coronavirus pandemic.</li>\n<li>In a September ABC News/Ipsos poll, only 35% of Americans said they approved of how Trump had handled the coronavirus pandemic, with 67% of respondents saying he acted too slowly to combat the disease.</li>\n<li>Later on Monday, Trump once again lashed out at Fauci, mocking his \"bad arm\" and saying he \"threw out perhaps the worst first pitch in the history of Baseball!\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President Donald Trump on Monday blasted Dr. Anthony Fauci, the top US infectious-disease expert, as a \"disaster\" in a campaign phone call, <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/us-election-news-10-19-2020/h_dfd35d9cb231f19b0f870af6f13c55e1\">CNN reported</a>.</p><p>Trump, who has downplayed the severity of the coronavirus as it has spread throughout the US, dismissed Fauci's health recommendations and claimed that more people would have died had he listened to the longtime health official.</p><p>Trump described Fauci as a \"nice guy\" who has \"been here for 500 years,\" then said, \"Fauci is a disaster,\" according to CNN, which said it got access to the call via a source.</p><p>\"If I listened to him, we'd have 500,000 deaths,\" Trump reportedly said, adding: \"People are saying whatever. Just leave us alone. They're tired of it. People are tired of hearing Fauci and all these idiots.\"</p><p>Trump revised the figure to 700,000 or 800,000 deaths before expressing indifference about whether his statements would reach reporters, CNN said.</p><p>\"If there's a reporter on, you can have it just the way I said it, I couldn't care less,\" he said, according to CNN.</p><p>Fauci has been the head of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases since 1984 and was recently part of the White House's coronavirus task force.</p><p>Trump's criticisms of Fauci had been relatively muted until recently. While <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-again-receives-poor-marks-on-response-to-coronavirus-2020-9\">Trump has struggled for months</a> with unfavorable opinions about his handling of the coronavirus outbreak, Fauci has remained one of the most trusted sources for health information.</p><p>In a September <a href=\"https://www.ipsos.com/en-us/news-polls/abc-too-slow-on-pandemic\">ABC News/Ipsos poll</a>, only 35% of Americans said they approved of how Trump had handled the coronavirus pandemic, with 67% of respondents saying he acted too slowly to combat the disease.</p><p>In an <a href=\"https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/6938425/200266-NBCWSJ-June-Poll.pdf\">NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll</a> in June, 50% of respondents said they viewed Fauci favorably, while only 11% said they had a negative view. And in a <a href=\"http://files.kff.org/attachment/Topline-KFF-Health-Tracking-Poll-September-2020.pdf\">Kaiser Family Foundation poll</a> released in September, 68% of respondents said they had a great deal or fair amount of trust in Fauci when it came to the updates about the coronavirus.</p><p>In an <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/video/fauci-covid-cases-increase-latest-60-minutes-2020-10-18/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"28b3d7041a4075ec82bd9cf3362baa73\">interview with CBS's \"60 Minutes\"</a> that aired on Sunday, Fauci said he was \"absolutely not\" surprised that Trump caught the coronavirus.</p><p>\"I was worried that he was going to get sick when I saw him in a completely precarious situation of crowded, no separation between people, and almost nobody wearing a mask,\" he said, referring to the White House ceremony for Trump's Supreme Court nominee, Judge Amy Coney Barrett, on September 26.</p><p>\"When I saw that on TV, I said, 'Oh my goodness. Nothing good can come out of that. That's got to be a problem,'\" Fauci continued. \"And then sure enough, it turned out to be a superspreader event.\"</p><p>Trump announced on October 2 that he and first lady Melania Trump had contracted the coronavirus. He was transported later that day to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center for treatment, and he was released on October 5.</p><p>The president has routinely dismissed the threat of COVID-19, urging state leaders to reopen businesses and claiming that <a href=\"https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/515223-trump-maintains-us-rounding-the-turn-on-coronavirus\">the US is \"rounding the turn\" on the pandemic</a> and that the virus will \"disappear.\"</p><p>But Fauci offered a different perspective, telling CBS: \"When you have a million deaths and over 30 million infections globally, you cannot say that we're on the road to essentially getting out of this. So quite frankly I don't know where we are. It's impossible to say.\"</p><p>In the interview, Fauci also said that his media appearances hadn't always been in his control.</p><p>\"During this pandemic, has the White House been controlling when you can speak with the media?\" Dr. Jon LaPook asked.</p><p>\"You know, I think you'd have to be honest and say yes,\" Fauci replied. \"I certainly have not been allowed to go on many, many, many shows that have asked for me.\"</p><p>Trump took another swing at Fauci on Monday afternoon, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realdonaldtrump/status/1318252740431155200?s=21\">this time on Twitter</a>.</p><p>\"Dr. Tony Fauci says we don't allow him to do television, and yet I saw him last night on @60Minutes, and he seems to get more airtime than anybody since the late, great, Bob Hope,\" Trump said. \"All I ask of Tony is that he make better decisions.\" The president also accused Fauci of saying \"no masks &#38; let China in.\"</p><p>Trump went on to mock Fauci's ceremonial first pitch of the first 2020 MLB game between the Washington Nationals and the New York Yankees in July.</p><p>\"Also, Bad arm!\" Trump wrote, adding that Fauci \"threw out perhaps the worst first pitch in the history of Baseball!\"</p><p>Before a rally in Prescott, Arizona, on Monday afternoon, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/atrupar/status/1318260842471751683?s=20\">Trump pushed back on the notion</a> that he was criticizing Fauci because of Fauci's favorability among Americans.</p><p>\"We let him do what he wants to do. He gets a lot of television. He loves being on television,\" Trump said, adding, \"But he's called a lot of bad calls.\"</p><p><em>This article has been updated.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/anthony-fauci-donald-trump-coronavirus-restrictions-election-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/mrjAETUnOyQ\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 18:30:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8db6acc21cfb0019468c88?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"0d7f91c0b4dbae610f59b9c942c8ca94","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn28@2020_6/2020/10/20/02-05-13-954_55ff650068801503.webp","destWidth":3199,"destHeight":2400,"sourceBytes":229856,"destBytes":229856,"author":"insider@insider.com (John L. Dorman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8db6999e9fe4001900a18e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn16@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-16-570_87fd227d828e9df0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn92@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-22-912_62ac3b7e8eeb256a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn16@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-20-091_682c87307e9b3ca7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/20/02-05-18-571_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mrjAETUnOyQ:yrH7tPo-ywo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn36@2020_4/2020/10/20/02-05-22-650_c31af1c9212a8adb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/mrjAETUnOyQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn75@2020_2/2020/10/20/02-05-22-757_d7e354908578b149.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603159473335},{"createdTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","updatedTime":"2020-10-20 10:04:33","title":"An unused Carnival cruise ship could soon become a floating office where techies, YouTube influencers, and 'digital nomads' can live and work remotely","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/cruise-ship-tech-office-remote-work-ocean-builders-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8df369c21cfb0019468e0a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"carnival cruise ship\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Carnival Panorama cruise ship sits docked, empty of passengers, as the global outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continues, in Long Beach, California, U.S., April 16, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lucy Nicholson/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A company wants to turn a cruise ship into a floating \"Crypto Cruise Ship\" office for now remote techies, \"digital nomads,\" YouTube influencers, startups, and more.</li>\n<li>Ocean Builders is in the final stages of obtaining a ship from Carnival Cruises that would eventually house over 2,000 people in its 777 cabins, priced between $25,000 and $50,000, per a report from The Telegraph.</li>\n<li>Guests would have access to fitness classes, a swimming pool, and a 5,000-square-foot theatre. Move-ins could start start as soon as January 2021.</li>\n<li>The unconventional office setup represents a burgeoning industry that is catering to remote work as people are free to live where they wish while offices remain shuttered.</li>\n<li>According to the company's website, the ship will use \"the newest cruise industry health and safety standards\" such as onboard testing and \"preventative doses of hydroxychloroquine,\" the anti-malaria drug that studies have found to be ineffective against treating the coronavirus.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A company wants to take a Carnival cruise ship, rendered useless by the COVID-19 pandemic, and turn it into a floating office for tech workers as the industry shifts to remote work.</p><p>The project, first reported by <a href=\"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2020/10/19/calls-silicon-valley-elites-join-floating-offices-sea/\">The Telegraph's Margi Murphy</a>, is dubbed <a href=\"https://ocean.builders/cruiseship/\">\"The Crypto Cruise Ship\"</a> and is designed as an entrepreneurial incubator for crypto enthusiasts, digital nomads, YouTube influencers, startups, and other like-minded folks. Guests will have access to yoga and fitness classes, meditation services, a swimming pool, a running track, and more. There's also a 5,000-square-foot theatre for workshops, conventions, movies, and live performances.</p><p>\"Just like the man-made island of Venice Italy became an important center of commerce in the old world, we believe this could be the start of a modern floating Venice of the Americas and an important hub of innovation in the world,\" reads the <a href=\"https://ocean.builders/cruiseship/\">website.</a></p><p>Ocean Builders founder Chad Elwartowski told The Telegraph that he is in the final stages of obtaining a ship from Carnival Cruises for an undisclosed sum that will host over 2,000 people in its 777 cabins. If the acquisition goes through, the company will start auctioning the first batch of 100 rooms on November. 5, which will range in price from $25,000 and $50,000. It's unclear what those rates cover and how long guests would be renting the rooms.</p><p>Ocean Builders did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment.</p><p>Bidding for the rooms will close on November 28, and guests will be able to move in starting in January when the ship, the MS Satoshi, will be anchored off the coast of Panama.</p><p>According to the website, all businesses onboard will accept payment in the form of bitcoin and USD, as well as other forms of payment.&#160;</p><p>Cruise ships have made headlines since the start of the pandemic as they were proven to be Petri dishes for the spread of the coronavirus disease, with <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-diamond-princess-cruise-ship-coronavirus-quarantine-went-wrong-2020-2\">vessels like the Diamond Princess ending up with hundreds of cases</a>. The pandemic has battered the cruise industry, prompting many lines — <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/carnival-coronavirus-covid-19-diamond-grand-princess-zaandam-2020-7\">including the biggest, Carnival Corp.</a> — to resort to layoffs and offloading their fleets of vessels.</p><p>Ocean Builders said on its website that it believes a \"properly run cruise ship can be the healthiest and safest place in the world to live\" and intends to use the \"newest cruise industry health and safety standards\" to create a safe environment onboard. That will include onboard health testings, medical facilities, a pharmacy, and doses of hydroxychloroquine, the anti-malaria drug that has been incorrectly touted by President Trump as a cure for the coronavirus disease. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-hydroxychloroquine-side-effects-coronavirus-2020-6\">Medical experts have advised against its use,</a> and FDA studies have shown that it has no effect on improving symptoms or someone's chances of survival after being infected with the disease.</p><p>\"If you are concerned about catching the flu you have the option to wearing a mask, social distancing, or taking preventative doses of hydroxychloroquine,\" the cruise's website states, seemingly referring to the coronavirus disease as \"the flu.\"</p><p>The company's endeavor to create an unconventional work setup represents a growing industry that is catering to a mass shift to remote work during the COVID-19 pandemic. Many have been freed from having to live near now-closed corporate offices and have subsequently been deprived of the usual perks that come with working in the region, such as free snacks and in-house massages.</p><p>Google has announced that employees will be working remotely through summer 2021, and some firms like Dropbox, Twitter, and Slack have told employees that they may work remotely permanently if they choose. Facebook has said that those who wish to leave the pricey San Francisco Bay Area for more affordable locales will <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/21/technology/facebook-remote-work-coronavirus.html\">likely have to take a pay cut.</a>&#160;</p><p>As for turning to floating accommodations for live-and-work purposes, this isn't Silicon Valley's first time to entertain such a notion. Ex-Googler Patri Friedman, founder of the nonprofit think tank Seasteading Institute, told The Telegraph in a June interview that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/silicon-valley-elite-seasteads-floating-city-pandemic-2020-6\">he's seen an increase in interest in seasteads</a>, or floating cities that operate independently of existing governments.&#160;</p><p>Friedman also once drafted designs for a would-be floating settlement in the Bay Area that would be \"Burning Man meets Silicon Valley meets the water.\" The idea inspired BlueSeed, a startup that set out to launch a so-called \"Googleplex of the seas\" in 2013 as&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/blueseed-entrepreneurs-concept-vessels-images-2011-12\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"7a966383e187d1c145c4b6747b11ecac\">Business Insider reported in 2011.</a></p><p>The company sought to skirt US regulations by building vessels on international waters near the Bay Area that would serve as incubators for tech workers who were unable to obtain US work visas. It was backed by billionaire investor Peter Thiel but never panned out.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/cruise-ship-tech-office-remote-work-ocean-builders-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=wTgpbchEbLA:xyue0NJeZN0:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wTgpbchEbLA:xyue0NJeZN0:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/wTgpbchEbLA\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 20:37:58
